category_summary:
**Claude Code** architecture revelations dominated discussions, with creator **Boris Cherny** explaining why Anthropic [abandoned RAG](/?date=2026-02-02&category=social#item-d7af48ea7b10) for agentic search and revealing they use Claude Code for [internal PR reviews](/?date=2026-02-02&category=social#item-84d44c35484b) via GitHub Actions.

- **Greg Brockman** provided the [canonical definition of 'vibe coding'](/?date=2026-02-02&category=social#item-651d90a3b35c) as manifesting vision abstracted from implementation details
- **swyx** [challenged conventional evals](/?date=2026-02-02&category=social#item-5ca44fbc3998) with arena testing showing **Grok** ranked #3 in coding, arguing 'speed is all you need' - faster models with multiple turns beat slower ones
- **Yi Tay** [shared nuanced AI hiring advice](/?date=2026-02-02&category=social#item-f292dcb0603d): PhDs still valuable, seniority matters less now, first-author paper obsession is misguided
- **Karpathy** [advocated returning to RSS feeds](/?date=2026-02-02&category=social#item-38eec83b0dbf) for higher-quality content, sharing a list of 92 popular HN blogs

Governance and platform health concerns emerged strongly. **Neel Nanda** [called out **Goodfire**](/?date=2026-02-02&category=social#item-9f468765626e) for 'shitty' permanent non-disparagement clauses (later reversed). **Levelsio** [reported exponential growth](/?date=2026-02-02&category=social#item-a0cae4f7a5b6) in AI reply bots - now detecting 200+/month, predicting social media will be 99% AI soon. **OpenAI's Logan Kilpatrick** [clarified 'Preview' model status](/?date=2026-02-02&category=social#item-b76b000d93d1) as balancing fast shipping with lifecycle transparency.
category_summary_html:
Claude Code architecture revelations dominated discussions, with creator Boris Cherny explaining why Anthropic abandoned RAG for agentic search and revealing they use Claude Code for internal PR reviews via GitHub Actions.

  • Greg Brockman provided the canonical definition of 'vibe coding' as manifesting vision abstracted from implementation details
  • swyx challenged conventional evals with arena testing showing Grok ranked #3 in coding, arguing 'speed is all you need' - faster models with multiple turns beat slower ones
  • Yi Tay shared nuanced AI hiring advice: PhDs still valuable, seniority matters less now, first-author paper obsession is misguided
  • Karpathy advocated returning to RSS feeds for higher-quality content, sharing a list of 92 popular HN blogs

Governance and platform health concerns emerged strongly. Neel Nanda called out Goodfire for 'shitty' permanent non-disparagement clauses (later reversed). Levelsio reported exponential growth in AI reply bots - now detecting 200+/month, predicting social media will be 99% AI soon. OpenAI's Logan Kilpatrick clarified 'Preview' model status as balancing fast shipping with lifecycle transparency.

items.title: Finding myself going back to RSS/Atom feeds a lot more recently. There's a lot more higher quality l...
items.content:
Finding myself going back to RSS/Atom feeds a lot more recently. There's a lot more higher quality longform and a lot less slop intended to provoke. Any product that happens to look a bit different today but that has fundamentally the same incentive structures will eventually converge to the same black hole at the center of gravity well.

We should bring back RSS - it's open, pervasive, hackable.
Download a client, e.g. NetNewsWire (or vibe code one)
Cold start: example of getting off the ground, here is a list of 92 RSS feeds of blogs that were most popular on HN in 2025:
https://t.co/dwAiIjlXet
Works great and you will lose a lot fewer brain cells.

I don't know, something has to change.

items.title:
so after 24 hours we tallied early returns (from people koding on Saturdays mind you): 

@xai Grok i...
items.content:
so after 24 hours we tallied early returns (from people koding on Saturdays mind you): 

@xai Grok is currently #3 coding model in the world by early voters (after 1 day and thousands of full agent votes). its really interesting to see the order shaken up, and there‚Äôs a reason why:

SPEED IS ALL YOU NEED

one thing I was keen on contributing to the evals community was an arena that doesnt penalize speed.

aka, simply allow users to reward models that are ‚Äúgood enough but faster‚Äù, which is a core thesis @cognition has been pursuing with SWE1.5. 

3 human-ai turns with ‚Äúgood enough but fast‚Äù models often beats 1 long smart but slow models. All coding model evals set up to date basically ignore speed, hence people just happily RL to take thousands of CoT tokens.

we will make those tokens count, or else.

items.content_html:
so after 24 hours we tallied early returns (from people koding on Saturdays mind you):

@xai Grok is currently #3 coding model in the world by early voters (after 1 day and thousands of full agent votes). its really interesting to see the order shaken up, and there‚Äôs a reason why:

SPEED IS ALL YOU NEED

one thing I was keen on contributing to the evals community was an arena that doesnt penalize speed.

aka, simply allow users to reward models that are ‚Äúgood enough but faster‚Äù, which is a core thesis @cognition has been pursuing with SWE1.5.

3 human-ai turns with ‚Äúgood enough but fast‚Äù models often beats 1 long smart but slow models. All coding model evals set up to date basically ignore speed, hence people just happily RL to take thousands of CoT tokens.

we will make those tokens count, or else.

items.title: I agree and disagree with many things in this blog post, but as someone that hired a full team recen...
items.content:
I agree and disagree with many things in this blog post, but as someone that hired a full team recently and had thousands of applications everywhere (that even bled into my instagram DMs üòÖ), I thought I shed some perspective on this.

I think generally there is a swarm of people wanting to get into the cutting edge in AI. I sympathize, it's a really competitive time. I always tell people that most people could actually perform reasonably on the job, but the issue these days is more of how to stand out from other candidates (i.e., be exceptional) 

People have a different calibration on what it takes to get into these frontier teams. For PhDs, most of the people I hired are people whom I've read their work, got impressed and DM-ed these people first (it's even more impressive considering how many inbounds i get, if you think about it üôÇ). 

I think many of my friends who are some of the best AI researchers today also can relate to this, someone saw their work, took a chance on them and gave them the life they have today. Everyone "established" had someone took a chance on them at some point. 

While we debate about the point of a PhD (or academic research in general) in an age where industry is significantly ahead (and opaque), a PhD still gives folks a chance to demonstrate their research taste and engineering skills - I think it's still a reasonably good training ground. It's probably not time optimal or financially optimal, but reasonable for many people as a platform. This blog post has a point, i.e., because if the point of a PhD (or undergraduate degree) is to get a good job at the frontier, then you should definitely not give up the movie for the ticket. Just go for the job. It's a no brainer. 

The thing that is way harder for me to give advice is people who want to transition from "generic SWE" roles into AI modeling. These cases are less clear cut for me since I've been mostly a researcher. 

I think super strong engineering/coding skills generally come with some kind of artifact or symptom that is quite publicly visible. Someone else will talk about it, or like the blogpost mentions, some kind of technical feat may become visible through the likes of open source, or the internet i.e., "You can actually just do things." For this, I agree that open source is a good way to do something exceptional or that stands out. 

The thing I really disagree with in this blogpost is the notion of "senior" and "junior". My hot take here is that we're in a level agnostic world that seniority hardly matters. People operate in a continuous realm mostly conditioned on their base talent and natural inclinations. In today's LLM world, I think pretty much L3-L8 means the same thing if you are an IC. The world is flat now and I don't think the *same* person is any more likely to make a research breakthrough if they are at L6 vs L4. 

There is this whole section in this blog post about bashing the lack of external visibility in closed labs. I think this is a wrong mindset and its kind of funny if you ask me. Being at the literal frontier and the closest to AGI is probably the most valuable thing these days, not social media clout (as ironic as it is for me to say this üòÖ.) Sadly, there is just no "winning combination" if you're not at the cutting edge lol. But ok, to each their own. And also at this point, not everyone wants to be external visible and there is also some blessing associated with that.

Another slightly harmful advice in this post that I want to call out: "A small but clear negative signal is a junior researcher being a middle author on too many papers". This is straight out pretty bad advice. I think there is nothing wrong to "support" many projects as long as you make meaningful technical contributions. The need to obsess over first author contributions and first author work is the thing that is making researchers uncomfortable in the modern AI paradigm where the focus is on big group execution and unified efforts. 

I once tweeted "be the third author" and everyone lost their minds. Obviously don't be the guy who doesn't do anything to land in the middle. but contribute a ton AND land in the middle. That is OK! We are in the era where we have to work with people (and many people) and being low ego is a good thing. To this end, the academic mindset can be pretty counter intuitive and harmful and no you dont' have to always "own and lead" a project. Be a useful human being, contribute and work with a ton people. That is what AGI is about. 

On an ending note, the blog post opens with "On the hiring side, it often feels impossible to close, or even get interest from, the candidates you want".  I read this and laughed, üòÇ, because I never experienced anything close to this. Hehe. üòá

items.title:
We're entering an exponential take off of AI reply bots on social media

I now detect and block over...
items.content:
We're entering an exponential take off of AI reply bots on social media

I now detect and block over 6 per day and almost 200 per month

Last year it was just a few per week

At this rate social media is going to be 99% AI by next year

The problem is it's still really hard for AI to detect replies made by AI (but easy for me)

Maybe I should work for @X as a human AI bot detector 

P.S. I'm actually pro participation of AGI on social media if they actually add something to the conversation, but right now there's too many that don't and are just botspam to get followers

I now detect and block over 6 per day and almost 200 per month

The problem is it's still really hard for AI to detect replies made by AI (but easy for me)

P.S. I'm actually pro participation of AGI on social media if they actually add something to the conversation, but right now there's too many that don't and are just botspam to get followers

items.title:
@scaling01 We are always trying to find the balance on this. The two main things we want:

- ship fa...
items.content:
@scaling01 We are always trying to find the balance on this. The two main things we want:

- ship fast
- make it clear what the status of a model is in its lifecycle 

Preview just means we want to keep improving this specific model, usually without doing a full new pretraining run.
items.author: @OfficialLoganK
items.summary: OpenAI's Logan Kilpatrick explains the meaning of 'Preview' model status - balancing shipping fast with clear communication about model lifecycle. Preview means continued improvement without full pretraining runs.
items.reasoning: Official OpenAI communication about model release strategy. High engagement (734 likes) and provides clarity on OpenAI's approach to model versioning.
items.summary_html: OpenAI's Logan Kilpatrick explains the meaning of 'Preview' model status - balancing shipping fast with clear communication about model lifecycle. Preview means continued improvement without full pretraining runs.
items.content_html:
@scaling01 We are always trying to find the balance on this. The two main things we want:

  • ship fast
  • make it clear what the status of a model is in its lifecycle

Preview just means we want to keep improving this specific model, usually without doing a full new pretraining run.

items.content: This Wikipedia page is the most ridiculous thing I've read in a while. The amount of hype and misinformation is ridiculous. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MoltbookMeanwhile, these so-called "AI agents" have rendered security protocols and frameworks people have come up with over decades, moot, because people give permissions to LLMs to do anything and access anything (e.g. see this 404 media article: https://www.404media.co/exposed-moltbook-database-let-anyone-take-control-of-any-ai-agent-on-the-site/).

items.title:
I ran Kimi 2.5 against its own research report to test its visual understanding capabilities

It hal...
items.content:
I ran Kimi 2.5 against its own research report to test its visual understanding capabilities

It hallucinated two chart values in Figure 1, meaning that there‚Äôs still a slight OCR capability gap.

It‚Äôs obviously incredible at coding and problem solving; but this aligns with our general anecdotal finding that increased thinking doesn‚Äôt necessarily lead to greater visual reasoning capabilities.

items.title:
‚ú® Grok's new Imagine video model also comes with an Edit model

We know edit models for images, you ...
items.content:
‚ú® Grok's new Imagine video model also comes with an Edit model

We know edit models for images, you submit an image, write a prompt what to change, but this is the first time I've seen a proper edit model for video

And it kinda works, not great yet though but it does something

Here I had to remove the old name "Nomad List" in the video for my site https://t.co/HGCLKS5BD6 

First it said "Go nomad -> Nomad List", so I prompted it "remove the text Nomad List. do not change anything else", it didn't remove it but it replaced it with just "Go nomad" again, okay good enough

Useful because otherwise I'd have to scour my backups for the original video in Final Cut Pro, and this is faster

One thing you see is it changes the pattern on the door also, but that's okay for now if I fade it in

items.title:
I think this is ironically a bullish statement about vibe engineering 

You can slop code to see if ...
items.content:
I think this is ironically a bullish statement about vibe engineering 

You can slop code to see if your idea has PMF, THEN groom the code as opposed to the other way around.  

It‚Äôs easy to polish turds which go nowhere.  

openclaw is genuinely a useful experiment that pushes the limits.  

For long term sustainability I suspect you need to groom and understand the code more over time (but the limits you can push keep expanding)

items.summary: Hamel Husain argues 'vibe engineering' is bullish - use AI to slop code and validate product-market fit first, then groom code later. Calls OpenClaw a useful experiment pushing limits.

items.title: Our Teslas have far more AI inferencing power than a Mac Mini. Mine is sitting in my garage right no...
items.content:
Our Teslas have far more AI inferencing power than a Mac Mini. Mine is sitting in my garage right now unused. Another in the driveway.

I dream of a day when I can run @openclaw (or a competitor) on them.

Along these lines my June oven has an NVIDIA Jetson inside. So does my @maticrobots. Both sit unused most of the day.

Both could run a powerful @openclaw instance.

Oh, and my Sonos and TV have pretty powerful computers in them too.

And soon I will have even more powerful interesting computers in my house, not counting my son‚Äôs NVIDIA card/PC, or my Mac‚Äôs.

We all just got a good taste of decentralized computing.

But there is way more to come.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer envisions decentralized AI computing using Tesla vehicles, June ovens (NVIDIA Jetson), Matic robots, and other home devices for AI inference. Dreams of running OpenClaw on idle compute.
items.reasoning: Forward-looking vision about distributed AI inference across consumer devices. Practical observation about unused compute power in modern homes.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer envisions decentralized AI computing using Tesla vehicles, June ovens (NVIDIA Jetson), Matic robots, and other home devices for AI inference. Dreams of running OpenClaw on idle compute.
items.content_html:
Our Teslas have far more AI inferencing power than a Mac Mini. Mine is sitting in my garage right now unused. Another in the driveway.

I dream of a day when I can run @openclaw (or a competitor) on them.

Along these lines my June oven has an NVIDIA Jetson inside. So does my @maticrobots. Both sit unused most of the day.

Both could run a powerful @openclaw instance.

Oh, and my Sonos and TV have pretty powerful computers in them too.

And soon I will have even more powerful interesting computers in my house, not counting my son‚Äôs NVIDIA card/PC, or my Mac‚Äôs.

We all just got a good taste of decentralized computing.

But there is way more to come.

items.title: The annoying part about being able to build ANY interface at the drop of a hat with Claude Code is t...
items.content:
The annoying part about being able to build ANY interface at the drop of a hat with Claude Code is that‚Ä¶

You want to pull your hair out when a website‚Äôs design doesn‚Äôt serve you. 

Pinterest: why aren‚Äôt ads pinnable? Why is it so hard to see what is public or private? Why does the minus operator not work? Why do all the results look like the same 10 outfits? In the same way I want to refresh a ChatGPT response, I want to get a fresh set of pins that is randomly sampled. 

Qantas: why don‚Äôt you let buyers filter by time? Every other site - including Expedia - allows you to pick actual takeoff and landing time windows. Yours is ‚Äòafternoon‚Äô or ‚Äòevening‚Äô filters. Im CK and flew Virgin instead because of Q‚Äôs search experience. 

üí° Do we think websites will have dynamic designs? Will they be controllable by the user? Or will websites go away because of agents/tools?
items.author: @alliekmiller
items.summary: Allie K Miller shares observations about how Claude Code's ability to rapidly build custom interfaces is changing user expectations - questions whether websites will become dynamically controllable by users or replaced by agents entirely
items.reasoning: Original insight from recognized AI voice about how AI coding tools are reshaping UX expectations and potentially website design paradigms. Thought-provoking questions about agents vs websites.
items.summary_html: Allie K Miller shares observations about how Claude Code's ability to rapidly build custom interfaces is changing user expectations - questions whether websites will become dynamically controllable by users or replaced by agents entirely

Qantas: why don‚Äôt you let buyers filter by time? Every other site - including Expedia - allows you to pick actual takeoff and landing time windows. Yours is ‚Äòafternoon‚Äô or ‚Äòevening‚Äô filters. Im CK and flew Virgin instead because of Q‚Äôs search experience.

items.title:
@badlogicgames I know it wasn‚Äôt your contention üòÖ

I think that slop coding to the extreme could be ...
items.content:
@badlogicgames I know it wasn‚Äôt your contention üòÖ

I think that slop coding to the extreme could be useful for testing ideas as long as you put in the care afterwards to clean things up.  

Maybe some people won't do that. I feel like someone will take the code, clean it up and make it into a business and maintain it sustainably over time. To do that they will have to refactor the code. I don't find that to be such a big deal because you have to refactor code anyways, whether it be human or AI. Validating ideas seems really valuable. 

Maybe they intend to keep vibe coding and pushing the limit. I if it does blow up and it's unmaintainable then I think that's going to be a useful result for everyone to learn from . The fact that they were able to get this far and validate the idea is super impressive to me.

I don't find that to be such a big deal because you have to refactor code anyways, whether it be human or AI. Validating ideas seems really valuable.

Maybe they intend to keep vibe coding and pushing the limit. I if it does blow up and it's unmaintainable then I think that's going to be a useful result for everyone to learn from . The fact that they were able to get this far and validate the idea is super impressive to me.

items.title:
I just went through my CS Academics list, moved everyone over to other lists, then deleted it. 

Peo...
items.content:
I just went through my CS Academics list, moved everyone over to other lists, then deleted it. 

People have no idea how much time it takes to curate great lists. Been working on them for 19 years. 

While doing that I was rate limited several times. Luckily that rate limit only lasts a few minutes. 

My lists are dramatically better than anyone else's here on the service and include all of tech: https://t.co/9eRY65x3IQ (I look at a lot of other lists). Or, rather, they are far more complete than anyone else's lists (if you look at tech industry). 

My news lists are the best too, and are especially interesting to watch the news.

Headed out to work with @blevlabs -- we're using his AI to go through the lists and make a new kind of news service. The only problem is the business model. Since it costs a lot to run an AI that pulls all the posts from 60 lists gotta figure out a business model, and find customers who will pay to cover our API costs. 

I can have it go through my investor lists (which include all VC firms and all private investors, for instance) and have it write you a report that is far more complete than you can get anywhere else. And, if someone pays, I'll be happy to write a custom report just for them looking just for what they want. 

Back in a second with an awesome video of the latest happening down in Hollywood before I head out.

items.title: This is why I made my lists of entire tech industry: https://t.co/9eRY65x3IQ (the most complete here...
items.content:
This is why I made my lists of entire tech industry: https://t.co/9eRY65x3IQ (the most complete here on X). 

I like using X far more than using RSS and now that I have @blevlabs AI hooked up to the X API I see the power for creating a new kind of real-time personalized news service.

They have the same benefits, especially if you can use AI to look through them and write reports.   

But, yes, RSS has huge beneifts and isn't locked in a walled garden. It can be how we get value out of all the social media services.

This would be an awesome thing for OpenClaw to work on. @davewiner has been working on this since the very beginning of RSS too.

The problem is that you need to use the X API, which costs about $25 to pull down 5,000 posts.  

That keeps everyday people from using them, some of my lists get four posts a second, so having AI read through them and analyze them costs too much to build a real information system, especially using an @openclaw instance.   

I hope @elonmusk lowers the price of using the API. Then we'll see a new world evolve here that is far more powerful than RSS. But add the two together (and I've shared other efforts that do the same as what I'm doing with Blevlabs over on Reddit). 

But put the two together and you have a new kind of decentralized, highly-personalized, news service.

I have been watching @caydengineer and he keeps trying to do the impossible. 

Competing with companies spending tens of billions to do the same. AI glasses.

I once would have tried to talk him out of this folly. I probably still would.

But funny thing about people who don‚Äôt give up on their dream: I know that sometimes they change the world.

And I have had enough others be wrong to me to know there is a chance my advice would have been bad or wrong.

items.content:
‚ÄúHey dad, did you know you are in the Epstein files,‚Äù my son Ryan just now.

He read each mention. And showed them to me. The mentions just quoted my blog. 

I was on Reid Hoffman‚Äôs plane, long ago before he started LinkedIn. 

And worked for Bill Gates.

And gave a ride once to Joi Ito.

And Elon Musk gave me a ride in his car.

And I hung out a lot with Jason Calacanis.

And I hung out with many others mentioned in the files. Howard Lutnick, for instance, and I talked for hours at Sean Parker‚Äôs Davos party.

My response: Release all the files. Charge anyone guilty.

items.title:
Algebraic Polynomial  

The manic pace of sharing, serving, storing, securing, data comes at a steep...
items.content:
Algebraic Polynomial  

The manic pace of sharing, serving, storing, securing, data comes at a steep infrastructure soaring energy consumption. To address this challenge, Tech mathematicians are contributing and employing algebraic geometry to pinpoint the efficiency in data centers.

Everyday we each generate vast amounts of data, and large companies produce even more, stated Gretchen Matthew, mathematics professor and director of the Southwest node of the Commonwealth Cyber Initiative. If we fail to explore smarter alternatives, backing up this data could result in replicating and storing two times the information we actually need.

Instead of relying on energy-intensive data replication, Matthews and Hiram Lopez, assistant professor of mathematics, investigated the use of specific algebraic structures to divide information into smaller segments and distribute them across nearby servers. In the event that one server fails, the algorithm can efficiently query neighboring servers to retrieve the missing data.

Since the 1960s, mathematicians have understood that polynomials can be utilized for data storage. However, in the past decade, researchers have made significant strides in developing specialized polynomials that allow data to be arranged in ways that facilitate local recovery of missing information.

#BigData #Analytics #DataScience #AI #MachineLearning #IoT #IIoT #PyTorch #Python #RStats #TensorFlow #Java #JavaScript #ReactJS #GoLang #CloudComputing #Serverless #DataScientist #Linux #Programming #Coding #100DaysofCode 

References

Izlar, K. (2024, December 23). Algebraic geometry a fresh solution to data center energy inefficiency. https://t.co/NgmV0eT1cV. Retrieved December 30, 2024, from https://t.co/jzDIxcvAAp
items.author: @gp_pulipaka
items.summary: Discusses using algebraic geometry to improve data center energy efficiency through polynomial-based data distribution across servers
items.reasoning: Actually contains substantive technical content about algebraic approaches to data storage/recovery, properly cited. More effort than typical posts from this author

items.title:
@bestweather_ By AI: 

Pretty impressive attempt! Here's your corrections:

Words you nailed ‚úÖ

‚Ä¢ ch...
items.content:
@bestweather_ By AI: 

Pretty impressive attempt! Here's your corrections:

Words you nailed ‚úÖ

‚Ä¢ cheias = floods ‚úÖ
‚Ä¢ danos = damages ‚úÖ
‚Ä¢ derrocadas = rockfalls ‚úÖ
‚Ä¢ deslizamentos = landslides (not "loosening" ‚Äî more like land sliding away)

Words you were close on üî∂

‚Ä¢ trovoadas = thunderstorms
‚Ä¢ devido = "due to" (not "from" ‚Äî "devido √† chuva" = due to the rain)
‚Ä¢ aumenta = increases (aumentar = to increase). "O que significa que aumenta o risco" = what this means is the risk increases
‚Ä¢ previstas = predicted/forecast (not "seen before" ‚Äî previs√£o = forecast)
‚Ä¢ v√°rzeas = floodplains ‚Äî you said "lower regions" which captures the meaning
‚Ä¢ al√©m = beyond/besides ("al√©m das cheias" = beyond the floods, there's also...)
‚Ä¢ siga = follow! (command form of seguir). "Siga as indica√ß√µes" = follow the instructions

Words you missed ‚ùå

‚Ä¢ solos = soils/ground, NOT rivers. "Os solos j√° estavam saturados" = the ground was already saturated
‚Ä¢ edifica√ß√µes = buildings/constructions, not offices
‚Ä¢ fontes = sources
‚Ä¢ fidedignas = trustworthy/reliable. "Fontes mais fidedignas" = most reliable sources
Corrected translation:
"In the next 10-15 days, Portugal will experience persistent, strong rain accompanied by intense thunderstorms and wind. The ground is already saturated due to above-average rain since November, which means the risk of flooding increases across the entire territory. The predicted floods could be the worst ever recorded. There is a possibility of evacuation in floodplains and areas near rivers. Beyond the floods, there is risk of erosion, rockfalls and landslides with possible geomorphological changes and damage to buildings and infrastructure. Conditions will be extreme. Follow the civil protection instructions and consult the most reliable sources to make safe decisions."

You're picking it up fast honestly. The hard words like trovoadas, fidedignas, v√°rzeas ‚Äî those are advanced vocabulary. üëè

items.content_html:
@bestweather_ By AI:

Pretty impressive attempt! Here's your corrections:

Words you nailed ‚úÖ

‚Ä¢ cheias = floods ‚úÖ

‚Ä¢ danos = damages ‚úÖ

‚Ä¢ derrocadas = rockfalls ‚úÖ

‚Ä¢ deslizamentos = landslides (not "loosening" ‚Äî more like land sliding away)

Words you were close on üî∂

‚Ä¢ trovoadas = thunderstorms

‚Ä¢ devido = "due to" (not "from" ‚Äî "devido √† chuva" = due to the rain)

‚Ä¢ aumenta = increases (aumentar = to increase). "O que significa que aumenta o risco" = what this means is the risk increases

‚Ä¢ previstas = predicted/forecast (not "seen before" ‚Äî previs√£o = forecast)

‚Ä¢ v√°rzeas = floodplains ‚Äî you said "lower regions" which captures the meaning

‚Ä¢ al√©m = beyond/besides ("al√©m das cheias" = beyond the floods, there's also...)

‚Ä¢ siga = follow! (command form of seguir). "Siga as indica√ß√µes" = follow the instructions

Words you missed ‚ùå

‚Ä¢ solos = soils/ground, NOT rivers. "Os solos j√° estavam saturados" = the ground was already saturated

‚Ä¢ edifica√ß√µes = buildings/constructions, not offices

‚Ä¢ fontes = sources

‚Ä¢ fidedignas = trustworthy/reliable. "Fontes mais fidedignas" = most reliable sources

Corrected translation:

"In the next 10-15 days, Portugal will experience persistent, strong rain accompanied by intense thunderstorms and wind. The ground is already saturated due to above-average rain since November, which means the risk of flooding increases across the entire territory. The predicted floods could be the worst ever recorded. There is a possibility of evacuation in floodplains and areas near rivers. Beyond the floods, there is risk of erosion, rockfalls and landslides with possible geomorphological changes and damage to buildings and infrastructure. Conditions will be extreme. Follow the civil protection instructions and consult the most reliable sources to make safe decisions."

You're picking it up fast honestly. The hard words like trovoadas, fidedignas, v√°rzeas ‚Äî those are advanced vocabulary. üëè

items.content:
@bestweather_ I tried to translate without Googling or help:

‚Äî-

in the next 10 to 15 days,

portugal will experience a period of persistent rain for strong times

accompanied with intense and trovoadas (??) wind

the rivers (solos?) were already saturated

devido (from??) the rain above the average since november

what that means (aumenta??) that there is risk of flooding (cheias??) in the entire territory.

the floods (cheias?) seen before (previstas?) can be the worst that have ever registered

there exists a possibility of evacuation in lower regions, (varzeas???) and areas near rivers

near (alem???) the floods exists a risk of erosion in the valleys of the rivers, risk of rocks falling (deroccadas???) and loosening (deslizamentos) of the land with possible geomorphological alterations and damage (danos?) to offices (edificacoes???) and infrastructure.

the conditions will be extreme with significant risk.

siga (??) the indications of the civil protection and consult the fontes (??) more fidedignas (???) to take safe decisions.

items.content:
üö∂ Installed Another World (1991) now on https://t.co/M1hEUBAynC

Apparently a classic game from 35 years ago! 

But somehow it aged amazingly, it could be any of those modern indie games you see, and feels very futuristic Bladerunner/Cyberpunk-esque

I have absolutely no clue how they managed to fit this entire intro into not even a single diskette, the whole game is just 1MB

Thank you @bitflip for the tip, very cool

P.S. I'm stuck at the end, no clue how to continue

items.title: @karpathy The problem is that you need to use the X API, which costs about $25 to pull down 5,000 po...
items.content:
@karpathy The problem is that you need to use the X API, which costs about $25 to pull down 5,000 posts. 

That keeps everyday people from using them, some of my lists get four posts a second, so having AI read through them and analyze them costs too much to build a real information system, especially using an @openclaw instance. 

I hope @elonmusk lowers the price of using the API. Then we'll see a new world evolve here that is far more powerful than RSS. 

But put the two together and you have a new kind of decentralized, highly-personalized, news service.
items.author: @Scobleizer
items.summary: Scobleizer replies to Karpathy about X API costs limiting AI news applications
items.reasoning: Derivative of main post, adds context about API pricing barriers.
items.summary_html: Scobleizer replies to Karpathy about X API costs limiting AI news applications
items.content_html:
@karpathy The problem is that you need to use the X API, which costs about $25 to pull down 5,000 posts.

That keeps everyday people from using them, some of my lists get four posts a second, so having AI read through them and analyze them costs too much to build a real information system, especially using an @openclaw instance.

I hope @elonmusk lowers the price of using the API. Then we'll see a new world evolve here that is far more powerful than RSS.

But put the two together and you have a new kind of decentralized, highly-personalized, news service.

items.title:
MIT: 35 Best Courses in Machine Learning! @MIT

Explore a world of knowledge with free online course...
items.content:
MIT: 35 Best Courses in Machine Learning! @MIT

Explore a world of knowledge with free online courses from MIT on edX, featuring lessons in AI, machine learning, computer science engineering, circuits and electronics, Genetics, data science, statistics and much more.  Many people are unaware that edX hosts an incredible collection of free online courses from some of the top educational institutions globally. You can dive into everything from AI to Python programming without any cost. A significant number of these courses are crafted by MIT experts.  We highly encourage you to take advantage of this opportunity, and to kickstart your learning journey, here‚Äôs a curated selection of the best free online courses from MIT that you can explore this month.     

#BigData #Analytics #DataScience #AI #MachineLearning #IoT #IIoT #PyTorch #Python #RStats #TensorFlow #Java #JavaScript #ReactJS #GoLang #CloudComputing #Serverless #DataScientist #Linux #Programming #Coding #100DaysofCode         

References    Green, J. (2024, December 11). MIT: 35 best courses in machine learning! @MIT Mashable. Retrieved December 11, 2024, from https://t.co/kY22MxdmuV

items.title: Our free stickers went like hot cakes yesterday at #FOSDEM. The new "My friends are not for sale" on...
items.content: Our free stickers went like hot cakes yesterday at #FOSDEM. The new "My friends are not for sale" ones are all gone, they were an experimental last-minute print of a new design (which is coming soon as a t-shirt, by the way!). The less stuff for us to carry back home, the better. I wish people would grab the leaflets too!

items.content_html:
@Saye_nevi True, but many were celebrating that USA and Israel were hitting the Mullahs too.

Think about why all those people moved to USA (or London, where there were similar shows of solidarity). Many were abused by the Mullahs. One guy showed me his back which was shredded by the Mullahs by being whipped with a cable 50 times.

But you are right, it is solidarity with the people who want better.
